message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the burnt areas suggests that the patient most likely suffered from deep-partial thickness (3rd degree) burns. The skin is mostly intact but the burn has penetrated deeply into the skin, resulting in tissue destruction, loss of pain sensation, and softness on palpation. Superficial burns only affect the epidermis, while superficial-partial thickness burns affect the epidermis and some portion of the dermis. Electric burns have a characteristic pattern of entry and exit wounds.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the burn, specifically the loss of pain sensation and minimal blanching, suggests a deep-partial thickness (3rd degree) burn. Superficial (1st degree) burns are painful and involve only the epidermis, while superficial-partial thickness (2nd degree) burns involve the epidermis and some of the dermis and are painful with blisters. Electric burns usually have a characteristic pattern and can involve deep structures such as bone and muscle, but the question does not provide enough information to suggest an electric burn.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The characteristics of the burn, including loss of pain sensation, minimal blanching, and softness, suggest a deep-partial thickness (3rd degree) burn. Superficial and superficial-partial thickness burns would not have loss of pain sensation and would have blanching on palpation. Electric burns can also cause deep-partial thickness burns.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the burned areas, including the blackened appearance and loss of pain sensation, suggest a deep-partial thickness (3rd degree) burn. Superficial-partial thickness (2nd degree) burns involve blistering and more pain sensation, while superficial (1st degree) burns only affect the epidermis and cause redness and pain. The option of electric burn is not supported by the given information.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The characteristics described suggest a deep-partial thickness (3rd degree) burn. The skin is blackened and charred, with loss of pain sensation and minimal blanching on palpation. Superficial burns affect only the surface layer of the skin and are red, painful but blanchable. Superficial-partial thickness burns involve the epidermis and superficial dermis, appearing red, painful, and will blanch. Electric burns may have similar characteristics but are often associated with deeper tissue damage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the burned areas being blackened and charred with loss of pain sensation and minimal blanching on palpation suggests that the patient most likely sustained a deep-partial thickness (3rd degree) burn. In this type of burn, the skin appears white or blackened and dry or leathery, and the affected area is firm or hard to the touch.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's burns affect 40% of his body and have blackened and charred appearance, indicating a deep-partial thickness (3rd degree) burn. The loss of pain sensation and minimal blanching on palpation also suggest a deep-partial thickness burn, as nerve endings and blood vessels are destroyed in this type of burn, resulting in decreased sensation and minimal blanching. Superficial-partial thickness (2nd degree) burns would have blisters on the skin surface and blanching on palpation. Superficial (1st degree) burns only affect the top layer of skin and result in redness and pain, while an electric burn usually occurs at the site of contact and can cause tissue damage as well as internal damage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of blackened and charred skin with loss of pain sensation and softness on palpation suggests a deep-partial thickness (3rd degree) burn. Superficial burns involve only the epidermis, while superficial-partial thickness burns involve the epidermis and upper part of the dermis. Electric burns may have similar presentations, but the history of being pulled out of a burning building suggests a thermal burn.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of blackened and charred skin with loss of pain sensation and minimal blanching on palpation suggests a deep-partial thickness (3rd degree) burn. Superficial burns have intact skin with redness and pain, while Superficial-partial thickness burns have blistering and more pronounced redness. Electric burns may also cause deeper tissue damage but the presentation may vary.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of blackened and charred skin, loss of pain sensation, and minimal blanching suggest that the patient suffered from deep-partial thickness (3rd degree) burns. Superficial-partial thickness (2nd degree) burns would have blisters and more significant blanching on palpation. Electric burns would have a different presentation with a visible entry and exit wound. Superficial (1st degree) burns would only damage the top layer of skin and have no blanching or loss of sensation.
